Introduction

Cystic fibrosis (CF) involves production of abnormally thick epithelial mucus leading to progressive scarring and dysfunction across multiple organs, particularly in the lungs, pancreas, liver, and reproductive systems.  It is the most common monogenic disorder, affecting ~1/3,000 live births, with ~1/25 Caucasian adults being carriers.

Pathogenesis

Genetics and molecular biology



CF is an autosomal recessive disorder due to inheritance of 2 abnormal copies of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene.  Mutations in CFTR result in a protein that is truncated (eg, G542X), is nonfunctional (eg, G551D), or fails to reach the cell surface (Î”F508).  Î”F508 is the most common mutation, accounting for ~70% of CF cases.  Î”F508 (ie, deletion of phenylalanine at position 508) leads to misfolding and subsequent proteasomal degradation of the CFTR protein (

figure 1
).  Approximately 2,000 mutations of CFTR have been discovered, but only a minority are clinically consequential (ie, variable penetrance).  Compound heterozygosity with 2 alleles can also produce significant CF clinical disease (
figure 2
).  The CFTR protein is an apical (ie, lumen-facing) epithelial chloride channel that actively (ie, using ATP) transports chloride out of the cell.  Movement of chloride creates an electrochemical potential that also draws sodium and water across the cell membrane, promoting hydration and thinning of mucus secretions.  The impact of CFTR depends on orientation of the channel, which is different at different sites (
figure 3
):



  • Mucosae:  CFTR is oriented outward, functioning to excrete chloride (as well as sodium, bicarbonate, and water) into the lumen.  Abnormal CFTR function results in desiccated, thick mucus that clogs organ lumens (eg, airways, pancreaticobiliary ducts), leading to clinical manifestations of recurrent pneumonias and pancreatic failure.
  • Eccrine sweat glands:  CFTR is oriented inward, functioning to remove chloride from the sweat (creates hypotonic sweat relative to plasma).  Abnormal CFTR function results in hypertonic sweat with elevated chloride and sodium (eg, salty).  This forms the basis of the ionophoric sweat chloride test.

Bronchiectasis



Cilia are an insufficient defense against the viscous ("sticky") CF mucus.  Mucostasis in the sinuses and airways leads to bacterial trapping, colonization, overgrowth, chronic infection, and recurrent bouts of sinusitis and bronchopneumonia.  Cycles of neutrophilic inflammation and bacterial infection lead to bronchiectasis (

figure 4
), with the bronchial walls progressively and irreversibly damaged and weakened.  This results in dilated, tubular, mucus-filled airways with increased collapsibility, leading to further obstruction and mucus retention.



Bacterial microbiology in CF-related bronchiectasis changes with age (

figure 5
).



  • In early childhood to adolescence, Staphylococcus aureus is the dominant colonizing and infectious pathogen. 
  • By adulthood, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common (~75% of patients are colonized), reflecting progression of bronchiectasis and biofilm formation. 


With progressive disease, patients are also at risk for colonization with Burkholderia cepacia complex, a fastidious gram-negative bacterium that is often difficult to eradicate and associated with increased morbidity and mortality.

Clinical presentation



Manifestations of CF reflect mucus clogging in various organs causing a direct and indirect effects (

figure 6
).

Constitutional



  • Cachexia or failure to thrive (eg, slow childhood growth curves) due to chronic/recurrent respiratory infections and nutrient deficiencies (eg, fat malabsorption from exocrine pancreatic failure)

Sinopulmonary



  • Sinuses:  acute and chronic sinusitis; nasal polyps (hyperplastic)
  • Airways:  bronchiectasis (dilation, thick mucus, obstruction) with intermittent acute exacerbations (similar to pneumonia); allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ) (eg, asthmatic wheezing, bronchiectasis with mucus plugs and brownish sputum, high IgE) due to fungal spore trapping and hypersensitivity
  • Lung parenchyma:  postinflammatory fibrosis (eg, from previous pneumonias and bronchiectasis exacerbations)
  • Heart:  secondary pulmonary hypertension (cor pulmonale); right ventricular failure; digital clubbing due to chronic mucopurulent lung disease

Gastrointestinal



  • Pancreatic:  acute and chronic pancreatitis (autodestruction by unreleased pancreatic enzymes), CF-related diabetes (endocrine insufficiency), fat and protein maldigestion and malabsorption (exocrine insufficiency) due to decreased secretion of proteases and lipases
  • Luminal:  meconium ileus (neonatal) and distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (adult equivalent), chronic constipation (often severe), large bowel obstruction, gut dysmotility, and bacterial overgrowth
  • Hepatobiliary:  gallbladder sludging, cholelithiasis and acute gallstone disease (eg, cholecystitis), cholestatic liver disease (can progress to cirrhosis), fat soluble vitamin (vitamins A, D, E, and K [ADEK]) deficiency (eg, coagulopathy)

Reproductive



  • Obstructive azoospermia Â± congenital bilateral absence of vas deferens (~100% male infertility)
  • Fallopian tube dysfunction (~20% female infertility)

Other



  • Musculoskeletal:  osteopenia, osteoporosis, and fractures (eg, vitamin D malabsorption)
  • Cutaneous:  severe aquagenic wrinkling (eg, palms and soles)

Diagnosis

Chest imaging



  • Bronchiectasis:  Chest x-ray is insufficient to visualize bronchiectasis but may show a generally "dirty" appearance with increased bronchial markings and hazy peribronchial fibrosis (
    image 1
    ).  CT (preferably high-resolution chest CT) more clearly shows the characteristic signs of bronchiectasis including airway wall thickening, dilation (bronchoarterial diameter ratio >1, creating a "signet ring"), and lack of bronchial tapering (airways maintain their same caliber beyond the peripheral 1/3 of the lung) (
    image 2
    ).  The thickened walls with lack of tapering lead to cylindrical airway segments, appearing as parallel "tram tracks" when viewed in a radiographic plane (
    image 3
    ).  Copious mucus impaction (ie, secretions in dilated airways) is also commonly seen. 
  • Fibrosis:  Patchy and nodular scarring are seen diffusely throughout the lungs but mostly in a bronchocentric distribution, due to repeated episodes of infection and inflammation.
  • Bronchiectasis progresses from cylindrical (early) to cystic (end-stage), where the extensive dilation of the distal airways causes them to appear as cystic spaces, similar to a bunch of grapes (
    image 4
    ). 
  • The combination of cysts and fibrosis (also seen in the pancreas) gives CF its name. 

Pulmonary function testing



  • Although bronchiectatic airways are dilated, they are hypercollapsible (weakened walls).  Expiratory collapse, combined with mucus impaction, leads to a predominantly obstructive pattern (ie, FEV1/FVC <0.7) on spirometry.  With extensive fibrosis, a restrictive component can be seen as well.

Diagnostic approach



Diagnosis of CF involves a combination of a positive clinical screen PLUS evidence of CFTR dysfunction (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).



Today, newborn screening with confirmatory positive sweat chloride diagnoses the vast majority of cases.  Occasionally, older patients (especially those with lower penetrance mutations causing slower disease progression) can be diagnosed retroactively based on clinical features and follow-up CFTR testing.  CF is sometimes first evaluated during investigations for infertility.



Some patients with suspected CF have intermediate results (eg, <2 major CFTR mutations, intermediate sweat chloride levels [30-59 mmol/L]).  In these cases, more intensive workup is needed (expanded DNA analysis [whole-gene sequencing], nasal epithelial potential difference, fecal elastase measurement, semen analysis).

Universal newborn screening



The inclusion of CF in newborn screening (NBS) along with other genetic conditions (eg, phenylketonuria, aminoacidurias) is now widespread (eg, all 50 states in the United States).  Early detection of CF reduces mortality, slows lung disease progression, and improves growth and developmental outcomes.



NBS involves sequential testing using the following methods:



  • Immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT):  IRT detects elevated levels of trypsinogen (a propeptide of trypsinogen) that accumulates in the blood due to defective pancreatic secretion.
  • DNA mutation screen:  DNA mutation screen is a PCR-based assay that detects the 40 most common CFTR mutations (accounting for ~85% of cases in Caucasians). 


When NBS is positive, infants undergo confirmatory testing with a pilocarpine sweat chloride assay.



The incidence of CF remains stable (~1/3000 births) due to unchanging prevalence of mutant CFTR alleles.  This is likely because carriers of CFTR mutation (ie, heterozygous) are asymptomatic and have normal fertility, and CFTR disease (ie, homozygous) is not embryonically lethal.  The persistence of abnormal CFTR may have served an evolutionary purpose (eg, protection against chloride-wasting diarrheal illnesses such as cholera).

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of CF can be considered based on the primary presentation:



  • Bronchiectasis and recurrent pulmonary infections
  • Obstructive lung disease and hepatic or pancreatic disease
  • Delayed meconium passage


These are explored in more detail in the following sections.

Bronchiectasis and recurrent pulmonary infections



CF causes bronchiectasis and frequent respiratory infections.  However, several other conditions are on the differential.  Similar to the framework for recurrent pneumonia (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
), they are conceptualized based on whether the bronchiectasis is diffuse or focal.

Diffuse bronchiectasis (bilateral, multiple lobes)



  • Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ) is caused by mutations in dynein and kinesin (rotational motor proteins).  Immotile cilia lead to mucostasis, bacterial overgrowth, and widespread bronchiectasis.  Unlike CF, PCD is associated with additional features such as organ heterotaxy (eg, situs inversus, dextrocardia).  Individuals with PCD typically have normal growth (versus failure to thrive in CF) and preserved gastrointestinal, nutritional, and pancreatic function.  Finally, infertility in PCD is due to paralyzed spermatozoa (defective flagella) rather than obstruction or absence of the vas deferens in CF.
  • Primary immunodeficiency (eg, agammaglobulinemia) is caused by marked depletion of B lymphocytes and immunoglobulin levels (especially IgA, IgG, IgM) in humoral immunodeficiency (eg, Bruton X-linked) or combined immunodeficiency (eg, severe combined immune deficiency [SCID] or severe cases of common variable immune deficiency [CVID]).  Recurrent pneumonia and dysregulated inflammation causes widespread bronchiectasis.  Chronic diarrhea (rather than constipation in CF) is common and infections frequently occur in extrapulmonary sites (eg, skin and soft tissue abscesses) as well.

Focal bronchiectasis (unilateral, single lobe)



  • Anatomic obstruction is caused by airway blockage by foreign body (eg, aspirated lego piece), extrinsic compression (eg, mediastinal lymphadenopathy), or intrinsic obstruction (eg, endobronchial lung cancer).  Obstruction causes stagnation of mucus in the downstream lobe, leading to recurrent episodes of post-obstructive pneumonia, airway damage, and regional bronchiectasis.  The offending lesion can often be seen on chest imaging or bronchoscopy.
  • Recurrent aspiration is caused by repeated aspiration pneumonia (gastric acid + oral flora), mainly in the setting of dysphagia (eg, dementia, stroke) or esophageal dysmotility.  History is characterized by several distinct acute episodes of pneumonia (ie, several hospitalizations), mainly with infiltrates affecting the right lower lobe.

Other causes of bronchiectasis



  • Traction bronchiectasis (eg, fibrotic interstitial lung disease) (
    figure 7
    ):  Parenchymal fibrosis (eg, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis) pulls the airways open as part of overall lung architectural distortion.  In contrast to the mucopurulent (ie, thick, viscous secretions) bronchiectasis in CF, traction bronchiectasis is bland (ie, dry cough) and not associated with chronic bacterial (eg, Pseudomonas) colonization.  Lung function is restricted (eg, volume loss in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis) rather than obstructed (eg, hyperinflation in CF).
  • Nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection (eg, Mycobacterium avium complex):  Chronic NTM infection is the most rapidly growing etiology of bronchiectasis in adults.  Risk factors include immunodeficiencies (eg, chronic oral corticosteroid use) and certain body morphotypes (eg, thin elderly women, named "Lady Windermere syndrome" after an elderly female character in a play who would suppress her cough due to her Victorian manners).  Like CF, constitutional symptoms (eg, cachexia) and chronic mucoid cough are common (but develop in adulthood).  Unlike CF, sputum analysis shows acid fast bacilli (instead of Pseudomonas or S aureus) and extrapulmonary symptoms are not seen. 

Obstructive lung disease and hepatic or pancreatic disease



Alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency can produce lung, liver, and pancreatic disease (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).



  • Like CF, pulmonary manifestations of A1AT deficiency include early onset obstructive lung disease in the absence of significant smoking exposure.  However, the lung disease appears in middle adulthood (vs childhood in CF) and most commonly involves panacinar emphysema (versus bronchiectasis and fibrosis in CF); less commonly, chronic bronchitis and bronchiectasis can be seen with A1AT deficiency but generally involve sterile inflammation (vs chronic dense bacterial colonization in CF). 
  • Like CF, extrapulmonary manifestations of A1A deficiencyT include liver disease and recurrent attacks of acute pancreatitis (due to imbalance protease activity).  However, the liver disease of A1AT involves a hepatocellular pattern (ie, â†‘ transaminases > bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase) of injury, as opposed to a cholestatic pattern (ie, â†‘ bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase > transaminases) in CF. 

Infant with delayed meconium passage



CF is the main cause of delayed meconium transit (ie, no passage within 48 hours after birth), leading to potential bowel obstruction in infants.  However, other conditions are on the differential (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
).



  • Meconium plug syndrome is a relatively benign and self-limited condition in which large amounts of normal meconium cause colonic obstruction.  It affects otherwise healthy neonates.  The colonic transition point is typically located in the descending colon (proximal dilation, distal narrowing) versus the ileocecal junction in CF-related meconium ileus (pancolonic narrowing).  The condition responds well to conservative management (eg, nasogastric decompression, osmotic enemas to evaluate meconium).
  • Hirschsprung disease represents congenital aganglionic megacolon (
    figure 8
    ).  Due to aperistalsis, the entire colon dilates, creating a transition point at the rectosigmoid junction (vs pancolonic narrowing in CF-related meconium ileus).  Clinical clues include a narrowed rectum and tight internal anal sphincter (due to failure of anorectal inhibitory reflex) on digital examination.  Diagnosis is made by suction biopsy demonstrating absence of myenteric ganglia. 


All 3 conditions can result in high-grade bowel obstruction (eg, abdominal distension, bilious emesis).  However, meconium plug syndrome and Hirschsprung disease produce dilation (megacolon) rather than narrowing (microcolon), and the meconium consistency is normal rather than inspissated.

Management of CF pulmonary disease

Stable disease



Chronic management of CF bronchiectasis prioritizes mucus clearance and infection prevention in order to avoid further airway remodeling and subsequent loss of lung function.



  • Airway clearance techniques (ACT):  Chest percussion (eg, manual hand clapping), huff coughing, high-frequency vibratory vest, and oscillating positive expiratory pressure (PEP) devices (eg, Acapellaâ„¢ flutter valve) are used to dislodge and mobilize thick bronchial mucus.
  • Mucolytic agents:  Nebulized hypertonic saline (eg, 6%) and nuclease therapy (eg, inhaled DNAse) help to rehydrate mucus and decrease viscosity.
  • Antibiotics:  Rotating inhaled antibiotics (eg, tobramycin, aztreonam) are given to decrease Pseudomonas burden.  Prophylactic macrolide (eg, azithromycin) is also employed for its anti-inflammatory properties.
  • Bronchodilators:  Beta agonists (eg, albuterol) can relieve inflammatory bronchospasm (eg, asthma overlap) and are often administered prior to other inhaled medications (to improve lung penetration).
  • Supportive measures:
    • Pulmonary rehabilitation (for all patients with functional limitation due to dyspnea)
    • Immunization against respiratory pathogens (eg, respiratory syncytial virus [RSV], COVID, Pneumococcus, influenza)
    • Supplemental oxygen (to maintain SpO2 >92%)
    • Noninvasive ventilatory support (for chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure)


Pulmonary function must be monitored closely (ie, regular spirometry to measure FEV1 is recommended every 3 months).  Patients can develop steep declines in FEV1, heralding an acute bronchiectasis exacerbation, even though their daily symptom may be relatively stable.

Acute bronchiectasis exacerbations



An acute bronchiectasis exacerbation (sometimes called a CF pulmonary exacerbation) is defined as an increase in symptoms (eg, worsening dyspnea, acute hemoptysis) and/or a significant decline in FEV1 (eg, â‰¥10% drop from baseline over several weeks).  Exacerbations are typically triggered by new infection (mainly respiratory viruses) or increasing burden of existing bacterial colonizers.



Management usually involves hospital admission for intravenous broad spectrum antibiotics consisting of antistaphylococcal and double antipseudomonal coverage (eg, vancomycin + cefepime + amikacin).  Sputum should be recultured to evaluate for emerging resistance.  A short course of glucocorticoids (inhaled Â± systemic) is often administered to patients with a bronchoreactive (asthmatic) component.  Other outpatient therapies (eg, ACT, mucolytics) are continued.



Bronchiectasis can erode into nearby bronchial arteries.  New hemoptysis signals exacerbation (reflecting heightened inflammation) and often resolves with antibiotic treatment.  Patients with life-threatening hemoptysis (eg, >240 mL/24h or causing worsening hypoxemia) should be intubated for airway protection and treated with bronchial artery embolization; chest physiotherapy is generally suspended until the hemoptysis resolves.

Management of CF extrapulmonary disease



Management of extrapulmonary CF mainly revolves around gastrointestinal and nutritional issues.

Endocrine pancreatic dysfunction (CF-related diabetes)



  • Annual screening with oral glucose tolerance test (preferred over HbA1c due to higher sensitivity) 
  • Antidiabetic drugs (eg, ~40% require basal insulin by age 40)

Exocrine pancreatic dysfunction (maldigestion and malabsorption)



  • Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, involving a mixture of digestive proteases, lipases, and amylase to assist in protein, fat, and carbohydrate processing respectively
  • Vitamin (ADEK) supplementation for all patients
  • Enteral (eg, nasojejunal tube) or parenteral (ie, intravenous) feeding for severe malnutrition

Cholestatic liver disease



  • Ursodeoxycholic acid (a choleretic agent) promotes bile acid flow and decreases biliary inflammation

Constipation



  • Daily bowel regimen (eg, sennoside [motility stimulant] + polyethylene glycol [osmotic agent]) to prevent constipation
  • Chloride channel agonist (eg, lubiprostone) for severe constipation

Osteoporosis



  • Regular DEXA screening (~20% have osteoporotic compression fractures by age 20)
  • Calcium and vitamin D supplementation, avoidance of systemic glucocorticoids, limited role for bisphosphonates

CFTR modulators 



In the last decade, several new drugs were commercialized that rescue aspects of CFTR function.  They operate via 2 main mechanisms:



  • Correctors (eg, lumacaftor, tezacaftor):  These drugs restore proper folding and stabilization of CFTR, allowing successful trafficking to the cell surface.  They are especially effective for mutations that result in CFTR misfolding and degradation (eg, Î”F508).
  • Potentiators (eg, ivacaftor):  These drugs increase the opening probability of CFTR, allowing for more effective transport of chloride.  They are especially effective for mutations that result in abnormal CFTR ion gating (eg, G551D).


The most common CFTR modulator regimen (elexacaftor-tezacaftor-ivacaftor) is a fixed-dose triple therapy that combines a potentiator and 2 correctors.  CFTR modulators are recommended for any patient with a responsive mutation; therefore, CFTR genotyping is the standard of care for all patients.

Prognosis



Survival in CF has steadily improved, with an unprecedented jump after the introduction of CFTR modulators (median survival increased from 40 in 2013 to 70 in 2023).  In terms of pulmonary status, most patients have complete resolution of respiratory symptoms and normalization of lung function.  In terms of extrapulmonary status, CFTR modulator therapy markedly improves virtually all aspects of organ dysfunction (eg, resolution of constipation, pancreatic insufficiency, and liver disease).  Because of their transformative impact, CFTR modulators have been deemed an "effective cure" (for patients with eligible mutations).



Despite these advances, the burden on patients is considerable.  For example, upon awakening, a typical teenager with CF must perform ACT (~30 minutes), followed by nebulized medications (~60 minutes), followed by oral and systemic medications (~30 minutes).  This routine is then repeated again in the evening.  Integrating these time-consuming (~5 hours/day) activities into school and daily life is taxing, requiring intensive support (eg, social work, mental health counseling) to help patients navigate their illness and to encourage adherence.



Some patients continue to suffer from progressive lung function decline with recurrent exacerbations.  They eventually require bilateral lung transplantation (referred once FEV1 â‰¤35%).  The most common cause of death in CF remains progressive respiratory failure, with gastrointestinal complications (eg, large bowel obstruction) a close second.

Summary



Cystic fibrosis (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 7
) is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting from mutations in the CFTR gene that impair chloride transport, leading to abnormally dehydrated mucus that obstructs and causes progressive dysfunction of multiple organs (eg, lungs, pancreas, gastrointestinal tract).  Î”F508 is the most common mutation (~70% of cases) and causes misfolding and proteasomal degradation of CFTR.



Clinical manifestations include chronic and recurrent sinopulmonary infections, bronchiectasis, pancreatic insufficiency, and male infertility.  Diagnosis requires the presence of a positive clinical criterion (eg, abnormal newborn screen) and proof of CFTR dysfunction (eg, elevated sweat chloride).  Most cases are diagnosed based on universal newborn screening (eg, immunoreactive trypsinogen) with a confirmatory sweat chloride test.  Management focuses on airway clearance techniques (eg, chest physiotherapy), mucolytic agents (eg, hypertonic saline), antibiotics (antipseudomonal), and CFTR modulators, which have dramatically improved survival rates and quality of life.  Despite these advances, cystic fibrosis remains a lifelong condition requiring extensive daily treatments and multidisciplinary care.
